Award.AwardTitle: Targeted Infusion Project: Bridging Alliances to Infuse Neuroscience at The Lincoln University (BrainLU)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue STEM graduate programs and/or careers. The proposed Bridging Alliances to Infuse Neuroscience at The Lincoln University (BrainLU) Targeted Infusion project aims to establish a neuroscience program in the Department of Biology at Lincoln University. This project seeks to diversify the pipeline of neuroscientists for the 21st century. BrainLU will train undergraduate students to think like scientists and immerse them in innovative research so that they can contribute to the advancement of neuroscience. The project is transformative as it brings an interdisciplinary approach to teaching undergraduate neuroscience and transitions undergraduate students to graduate education with high-impact learning experiences.

To attain the goal of establishing a neuroscience program, the following objectives will be carried out over the 3-year funding period: 1) train and engage underrepresented undergraduate students in innovative neuroscience research in the research laboratory and classroom; 2) establish an interdisciplinary major in neuroscience at The Lincoln University that fosters creativity and original thought and builds critical thinking, analytical, quantitative, and research skills; and 3) develop a dynamic cooperative 4+1 BS/MS program in neuroscience between Lincoln University and Drexel University College of Medicine that can lead to a PhD in neuroscience. The proposed activities are geared to excite students about cutting-edge neuroscience research, bridge collaborating partners, and leverage the existing NSF HBCU-UP LEAPS Forward March program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF Targeted Infusion Project: Bridging Alliances to Infuse Neuroscience at Lincoln University (BrainLU; award #1533763) addressed the need to increase the number of underrepresented groups in neuroscience by developing a neuroscience major at Lincoln University, developing a cooperative 4+1 BS/MS program in neuroscience with ally Drexel University College of Medicine, and providing research opportunities to students. Neuroscience is interdisciplinary, challenging, and intriguing by nature, but is sorely lacking racial diversity as a field. Lincoln University is the first degree-granting Historically Black College and University (HBCU) and is well poised to offer neuroscience as a major. Students have expressed a great desire for a neuroscience major and graduate school opportunities. Through the NSF BrainLU award and previous funding, the neuroscience teaching curriculum and neuroscience research infrastructure have been enhanced. A total of 196 Lincoln students have taken neuroscience courses since the implementation of the first neuroscience course at Lincoln in 2009 - with 134 of these students during the NSF BrainLU funding period. Perhaps, the most exciting of the neuroscience courses is the Neuroscience, Philosophy, and Art class, in which students presented their amazing final artwork to the Lincoln community. Thirty-seven students received research training in neuroscience, especially in health disparities in neurological diseases, during the academic year and summer at Lincoln University and Drexel University. Students have presented research data at national conferences (e.g., Society for Neuroscience Annual Meeting) and Lincoln University Annual Science Fair. Several student participants who have graduated are in medical, graduate, and other professional programs or are in the workforce. Publications were produced, and more research journal articles will be submitted. The neuroscience program aligns well with the mission and strategic plan of Lincoln to immerse students in a rigorous curriculum and produce well-informed global citizens.

Curriculum development of a neuroscience major and 4+1 BS/MS program in neuroscience has been the focus of the NSF BrainLU award. The Bachelor of Science (BS) in neuroscience and 4+1 BS/MS program in neuroscience will be housed in the Department of Biology at Lincoln University. New neuroscience courses were developed and taught as either Special Topics in Biology or Honors Seminar courses to garner interest and await approval of the major. The BS in neuroscience proposal was presented to the Biology Department, the former College of Science and Technology, and Educational Policies Committee at Lincoln and is currently being revised for resubmission. The revised proposal will be submitted to the department and appropriate faculty standing committees (Curriculum Committee, Educational Policies Committee, and Faculty Council) in January 2021 for final approval by the faculty and university. The PI at Lincoln and Co-PI at Drexel have strategized on how best to structure the 4+1 BS/MS program in neuroscience and plan to meet with Drexel University officials early 2021. To begin recruitment of Lincoln students to Drexel, one student enrolled in the MS program in neuroscience at Drexel but graduated from another MS program at Drexel. Another student was accepted into the MS in neuroscience program at Drexel in 2019 but decided to attend another university. Once the 4+1 BS/MS program in neuroscience is approved, three to four students are to enroll therein. The MS students could then transition more easily to the PhD in neuroscience program at Drexel.

With unexpected obstacles and the COVID-19 pandemic, the implementation of the major and cooperative 4+1 program has taken longer than expected. The goal is to have final approval for the BS in neuroscience in spring 2021 for a start date for students to declare the major in fall 2021 and the cooperative 4+1 BS/MS program soon after. Upon approval, Lincoln University, the first degree-granting HBCU, will have a unique neuroscience program that prepares African Americans and other underrepresented groups for further graduate study and to tackle the basic science of neurological diseases of an aging population globally.
